title: The Basics of the Gastrointestinal (GI) System
content: The GI system is basically a tube that begins at the mouth and ends at the anus. It’s hollow so the inside of the GI tract is really an internalized external space; it’s outside the body. If you bleed into your GI tract, you lose blood. This is one of the major crises in medicine‒ hidden bleeding in the GI tract. It can be very damaging, even if you don’t see any blood. The inside of your gut is outside of your body, and it provides a space for a community of extra organisms to live. This space is immense. This space can be dangerous and a barrier is necessary to keep it separate from the rest of you. This barrier is defended by the body. It also allows food to be digested and absorbed. It has to maintain the communication with the lumen, which is what we call the inside of the GI tract. There is a balance in the GI between protection of the body and allowing food stuff to come in.

title: The Early Development of the GI System
content: During development the body forms a flat disc. That disc undergoes a series of folds from head to toe, and from side to side, and the lateral or side folding produces the tube from which the gut forms. This takes place during the 1st trimester. The gut is fully developed between the 2nd and 3rd trimester. The first part of development is called embryogenesis. That is the fertilized egg forms the disc, the disc folds, the organs of the body form, and that’s the embryonic period. The fetal period follows. The fetal period models the organs into their appropriate developmental form so that they becomes functional enough to support a baby.

title: The Unique Properties of the Blood Supply and Portal System in the GI Tract
content: The foregut is defined as the part of the gut from the celiac artery. The celiac artery supplies the pancreas, the stomach, the first part of the duodenum, and the liver and the gallbladder. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the midgut. That’s the longest part of the gut. That goes roughly to the mid-transverse colon. The inferior mesenteric artery supplies the end of the gut. When the celiac gives rise to the stomach and first part of the small intestines arterial supply (that then breaks into capillaries, absorbs materials from the gut), those capillaries drain into veins in the gut. And in a unique way, those veins then form large vessels which then move into the liver. They then break into capillaries, small vessels within the liver called sinusoids. So the liver depends on this venous system for its oxygen on blood that the gut has had a first crack at.

title: An Overview of Gut Anatomy and Innervation
content: The gut has its own intrinsic nervous system, and Mike has called that “The Second Brain”. The reason he calls it “The Second Brain” is that like the brain in the head, the nervous system of the gut is able to function and control reflexes and behavior independently of any influence from the brain or spinal cord. So it’s the only nervous system of the body that can work on its own, so if you completely isolate the gut from the brain and the spinal cord, it will function; you’re not dead. Years ago, when peptic ulcers were thought to be psychogenic, surgeons used to cut the vagus nerves, which are the major conduits that connect the brain and the gut. Afterward, the gut continued to soldier on. This never did all that much to fix peptic ulcer disease; that turned out to be caused by infection with the bacteria Helicobacter pylori.

title: Gut Structure and Function
content: The gut consists of a loose nervous system called a lamina propria, a dense layer of connective tissue, a circular layer of smooth muscle, and another layer of smooth muscle called the longitudinal layer. The major parts of the nervous system of the gut are the submucosal plexus (the Meissner’s plexus) and the myenteric plexus. These plexuses communicate with one another and with the central nervous system (CNS). The gut and the brain have a constant two-way communication. The behavior of the gut is controlled by the bowel itself.

title: Gut Muscular Walls
content: The gut has two muscular walls. One of them runs longitudinally and the other runs circularly. The contraction of these layers permits the peristaltic rhythmic contraction of the gut.

title: Epithelial Lining Turnover and Cancer Development
content: The gut epithelium turns over about once a week. Certain cells in the lining of the gut, such as the Paneth cell, live for three weeks. Gut endocrine cells live a little bit longer. The rapid turnover of cells in the colon increases the chances for genetic errors of replication that can produce oncogenic mutations, making it susceptible to neoplasia (the formation of cancer).

title: Nutrient and Water Absorption in the Gut
content: Most nutrient absorption takes place in the small intestine while the large intestine mainly reabsorbs water. The large intestine also conserves/absorbs sodium and secretes potassium. However, the bulk of the water that the gut absorbs is done in the small intestine.

title: Gut and Brain Communication
content: The intrinsic nervous system of the gut represents the nerve cells that live within the gut. The extrinsic innervation includes the brain, the sympathetic nervous system, the spinal cord, and the ganglia associated with the spinal cord. The gut feels pain in response to dilatation or pressure. The CNS communicates with the gut, providing broad instruction but not necessarily minutia-driven, operational instructions.

title: Gut's Role in Appetite Regulation
content: Distension of the stomach tends to cause satiety and decrease the urge to eat. A rise of blood glucose is sensed by receptors within the gut which send signals to the brain. Enteroendocrine cells within the gut make hormones such as cholecystokinin, which can signal to the brain by going through the blood brain barrier to be received by neurons. Leptin is also made within the gut.

title: Appetite Communication Mechanisms
content: The 2 mechanisms through which appetite is communicated are mechanical and chemical. Mechanical communication occurs in the stomach and to a lesser extent in the small bowel. Information is transmitted from the gut to the CNS via the vagus nerve. The change in blood glucose is sensed directly in the CNS. This occurs because glucose easily passes through the blood brain barrier; so the gut doesn’t need to be involved.

title: Role of Gut Hormones in Appetite Regulation
content: Blood vessels that provide blood to the brain have transporters that allow certain chemicals from the gut, such as leptin and cholecystokinin to be transported so that they can affect the CNS directly. Ghrelin is another hormone from the gut that promotes appetite. Ghrelin secretion is affected by certain chemicals in foods eaten. Nutrients that suppress ghrelin secretion include amino acids and fatty acids. The natural state is secretion of ghrelin and it’s the presence of nutrients that turn it down. Ghrelin is secreted at a constant rate that can be turned up or down. Inhibiting secretion is important to prevent the development of the ghrelin effect.

title: Impact of Meal Type on Ghrelin Secretion
content: The type of meal affects ghrelin secretion. The rate at which the stomach empties varies tremendously depending on what you put into it. For example, if you just eat a saline meal, the stomach will empty much more rapidly than if there’s protein in it. And even protein will empty much more rapidly than if there’s fat in it. Solids also delay gastric emptying; particles can’t get through the pyloric sphincter unless they’re ground down to a millimeter or less in diameter.

title: Impact of Gastric Bypass Surgery on Satiety Signals
content: One of the most successful operations for the treatment of both obesity and Type 2 diabetes is a gastric bypass. This reroutes the upper GI tract. The gastric bypass triggers an emergency procedure in the small intestine to produce a larger satiety signal. People can ignore signals from the stomach when they overeat. Signals from the small intestine act as a back up signal to stop eating; it makes eating objectionable.

title: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) Infection in the Gut
content: The gut is a source of infection by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) (the virus of chickenpox and shingles). Shingles of the gut can occur; that can be very, very serious. After someone recovers from the chickenpox, VZV remains in the body (sleeping). Then, for reasons that are unknown, the virus can reactivate. This gives rise to the reemergence of active virus. Reactivation is called shingles (or zoster); this can be extremely painful because the nerve cells die and become extremely active (they’re pain nerve cells). About 15% of people develop postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) where the pain persists for years and is very difficult to treat.

title: Relationship Between Autism and Gastrointestinal Illness
content: Children with autism have an increased severity of illness and increased prevalence of gastrointestinal illness. Autism is a disease that probably involves synaptic transmission. It occurs in the CNS. The behavioral effects are well known. It also occurs in the enteric nervous system. There is a smaller effect on the GI tract‒ often diarrhea and sometimes constipation. There seems to be a higher degree of food sensitivities and allergies, which is not well understood but seems to be related to activation of mast cells.

title: Role of Serotonin in the Gut
content: Serotonin levels are higher in a subset of kids with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Serotonin was discovered in the gut. Enterochromaffin cells, which are an endocrine cell of the gut responsible for making about 95% of the body’s serotonin. The brain produces about 2-3% of the body’s serotonin. Serotonin in the gut sends important signals. Within the gut, serotonin is made in 2 places. 1 – The bulk of it is made by the enterochromaffin cells, which are the small endocrine cells that are part of the GI epithelium. 2 – The other source is serotonin-containing nerve cells within the enteric nervous system. It is a neurotransmitter and an endocrine substance in the gut. It’s very important in feeling pain in the gut; it’s important for triggering nausea. In sending signals from the gut to the brain, serotonin is an important transmitting substance. During development, serotonin is very important as a growth factor.

title: Effects of SSRIs on the Gut
content: SSRIs prevent the reuptake of serotonin, this neurotransmitter in the brain, presumably leaving more of it around to exert positive effects. They’re used to treat the symptoms of depression. They tend to cause nausea by enhancing the ability of serotonin to talk back to the brain. SSRIs also first make the gut go a little bit faster. But then when the gut keeps doing that, the receptors, that is the molecules upon which serotonin acts, desensitize. In terms of motility, they can make the gut go faster. Ultimately, they stop the gut and give rise to long term constipation, and have to be stopped. They are nauseating, they change motility.

title: SSRIs and Pregnancy
content: During development, if you give SSRIs to a mouse during fetal development (give it to the mother during fetal development), you get an abnormal nervous system grown in the mouse’s nervous system. They are used frequently and in large numbers, large amounts in pregnancy because pregnancy is very often associated with depression. Fortunately, they are most commonly used postpartum. But even then it’s a problem because SSRIs can be communicated to the child in breast milk. There is evidence that a number of conditions are increased in the offspring of mothers who are treated with SSRIs during pregnancy such as irritable bowel syndrome.

title: Defining Leaky Gut and its Causes
content: Consider the context of the enterocytes. On the luminal side, they have a never ending barrage of toxins, microorganisms, bacteria, viruses, food stuff that have to be absorbed. At the same time, they can’t be digested by these things. Anything that interferes with the tight junctions can make the channel open and allow material from the lumen to get into the body, but at the same time, allow material within the body to get into the lumen. It’s very dangerous to have material going into the lumen. Anything going into the lumen is lost from the body. If you open tight junctions in the lining of the gut, you can essentially flow out into your bowel. The most common cause of leaky gut is allergy (hypersensitivity) where the immune system is reacting and causing tight junctions to open.

title: Leaky Gut and Autism Spectrum Disorder
content: Is it thought that there is a causal relationship between leaky gut and autism spectrum disorder (ASD)? Or are these things that move together due to a similar underlying pathology? The problem in the gut in autism spectrum disorder is [it’s] a disorder of the nervous system. It has nothing to do with leaky gut. Leaky gut is part of the Wakefield hypothesis. There is no evidence this is correct. Is leaky gut seen more often in patients with ASD? Not really.

title: Autism and Gut Health
content: Mice with certain mutations exhibit behaviors similar to autism. This abnormality is seen in about 2% of ASD patients. The defect in the gut has to do with serotonin, and the ability of serotonin to act as a growth factor. There’s a deficiency in terms of numbers of neuronal cells in the bowel. In a patient with autism spectrum disorder, similar kinds of things happen. If you give a mother a SSRI, her pups get too many nerve cells growing in the gut. Gut motility becomes defective. If you knock out the transporter, you have too many nerve cells in the gut. If you make the transporter more active, you have too few nerve cells in the gut.

title: Gut Microbiome
content: The greatest number of bacteria are present close to the colon. The small intestine benefits from stomach acid because very few organisms are dumped into it. The small intestine neutralizes stomach acid. Small numbers of organisms entering the small intestine and its motility contribute to keeping the number of bacteria down in the small intestine. There are also cells (like Paneth cells) which make antibacterial proteins (called defensins) which help keep the lumen of the gut close to sterile. As you get closer and closer to the colon, these mechanisms are reduced and the number of organisms increases.

title: Bacteria in the Gut
content: Bacteria in the gut are able to get involved with the nervous system in a way that the bacteria of the skin do not. For example, the bacteria that are in the gut can activate lining epithelial cells, enteroendocrine cells to release serotonin, or other factors that can signaled by way of the vagus nerves to the brain. Chemical products that the bacteria make can also trigger nerve signals that send signals back to the brain, or even go through the blood brain barrier to affect the brain.

title: Fecal Transplants
content: Fecal transplants from lean to obese have been done. Fecal transplantation has an enormous potential. The only approved use currently is for infection with Clostridium difficile. Patients often develop a C. diff infection after taking antibiotics. Antibiotics knock out the bulk of bacteria in their large intestine. C. diff is resistant to these antibiotics so it emerges as the dominant bacteria. C. diff produces a toxin that causes massive diarrhea. The first step to cure C. diff is to take oral vancomycin; C. diff is sensitive to this antibiotic.

title: Gut Microbiome Diagnostic Tests
content: Commercial home kits that tell you about your microbiome are not yet useful outside of special cases such as cancer detection. The best kits are the ones that look for cancer, such as Cologuard. About 90% of GI cancer and be picked up effectively by Cologuard. But using this test doesn’t mean you don’t have to go also do colonoscopy. The goal of a colonoscopy is to find a polyp that’s going to become cancer, not wait until you have cancer.

title: Concerns about Commercial Health Tests
content: The problem with Cologuard is you may miss 10% of cancer; you don’t want that to happen. A lot of these tests are paired with supplements, or probiotics, or prebiotics that are supposed to “fix the defects found in the test”. There is a lot of noise created without a signal.

title: Nutritional Approaches for Optimal Gut Flora
content: One of the most important things nutritionally that people can do to make sure that they have the optimal flora for their gut. This is important for (1) general health maintenance and (2) after taking antibiotics. From a general maintenance principle, for someone who is not taking a lot of antibiotics and wants to do what’s best for your gut, nutrition is one of the most important levers.

title: Role of Balanced Diet in Gut Health
content: A balanced diet is better than the South Beach Diet, or one of those diets for losing weight. Having a balanced diet with appropriate nutrients, including vitamin C, and particularly fiber is good for your body. There’s no reason to have an excess of vitamin C.

title: Impact of Dietary Cleanses on Gut Health
content: Cleansing the inside of the gut is not a good thing to be doing. When people do dietary cleanses, they’re usually drinking a lot of water with pepper and presumably some nutrients; is this similar to doing a bowel prep? They are not killing the bacteria. But they’re not doing their body a favor by eating strange foods.

title: Importance of Insoluble Fiber in Diet
content: If people don’t eat much or any insoluble fiber, will this change their gut bacteria or impact their health negatively? Not much research has been done on the negative impact of low fiber. Research has focused on the health benefits of fiber and has found 1 – fiber can absorb toxins; it is thought to decrease their long-term carcinogenic effects 2 – It provides the colon something to “chew down on”; it’s good for motility and keeping the bowel going and in shape 3 – It provides food for bacteria of the colon.

title: Impact of Artificial Sweeteners on Gut Microbiome
content: There are bacteria that can metabolize these molecules. The net effect of this is not clear. The literature on this is self-contradictory. Some people think there are impacts. Some people think the effect is negligible.

title: Prebiotics and Probiotics after Antibiotics
content: If a person has to take a long course of antibiotics, what can they do to appropriately repopulate their gut? Probably taking appropriate probiotics at the same time they’re taking those antibiotics, or afterward, is helpful. Probiotic is defined as an organism that has beneficial effects; you eat them. Prebiotic is defined as material that will enable the body to grow organisms that have beneficial effect.
